answers: Trumbull [accept Jonathan Trumbull, Jr.; or John Trumbull]
parts: Name this first signer of the Bill of Rights who also served as the first U.S. Speaker of the House.

Frederick Muhlenberg was also the third Speaker of the House, with his terms being broken up by a member of this family, Jonathan. His similarly named brother John painted the signing of the Declaration of Independence.

Frederick Muhlenberg cast a deciding vote in favor of a contentious 1794 treaty with Great Britain named for this statesman, who served as ambassador to Spain and as the first Chief Justice of the Supreme Court.

answers: James Fenimore Cooper [accept "Fenimore Cooper's Literary Offenses"]
parts: Name this author who, according to a Mark Twain essay, commits "114 offenses against literary art out of a possible 115" in the novel The Deerslayer, which is about Natty Bumppo.

This critic called Cooper's Leatherstocking Tales "sentimental and ... trite, reassuringly platitudinous." This author's Love and Death in the American Novel grew from the essay "Come Back to the Raft Ag'in, Huck Honey!"
This Fireside poet wrote, "the women [Cooper] draws from one model don't vary / All sappy as maples and flat as a prairie" in the satire A Fable for Critics.

answers: one trillion times [accept the Trillion Tree Campaign]
Greta Thunberg [or Greta Tintin Eleonora Ernman Thunberg]
parts: Name this city. 2016 international discussions held in this city established a "sustainable development mechanism" to guide nationally determined contributions as measured by the Global Stocktake.

To mitigate heat waves, Hidalgo's government is planting trees as part of Thomas Crowther's UN initiative to plant trees this many times. The goal to plant trees this many times is a successor to a lesser goal developed by Wangari Maathai's Green Belt Movement.
Hidalgo has praised this teenage Swedish activist, who sailed across the Atlantic in a solar-powered yacht to speak at the UN Climate Action Summit.

Name this opera that ends with Valentine and Raoul being taken from a cemetery and killed by Valentine's father, the Count de St. Bris. Robert Schumann criticized this opera's use of Martin Luther's "Ein feste burg" in its overture.
Les Huguenots is a work by this French composer of grand operas like L'Africaine (lah-free-KEN) and Robert le Diable (roh-BAIR luh de-OB-luh).

This colleague of Meyerbeer praised the blessing of the daggers scene of Les Huguenots in his three articles analyzing it. This composer of the grand opera Les Troyens (luh trwa-YAN) also wrote Symphonie fantastique.

answers: visibly colored [accept answers indicating they have a color that isn't white; accept specific colors like red]
parts: Name these interactions formed between two atoms whose p orbitals overlap to give a single pi bond.
Various conjugated molecules like lycopene have this relatively rare property because the energy gap between their HOMO and LUMO is less than 3 eV (electron volts). A description is acceptable.

When modeling a conjugated system as a particle in a box, the lowest energy absorbance peak corresponds to this number times the zero-point energy. This multiple corresponds to the simplest possible transition between its energy levels.

answers: convents [or nunnery; or beaterios; prompt on monastery or abbey or priory with "What specific type of monastery?"]
Cape Horn [or Cabo de Hornos; or Kaap Hoorn]
parts: João Pinto described how Indian men were frequently forced into slavery at these locations in Evora. Teresa of Ávila retired to one of these places where she founded the Discalced (dis-KAHLSS'd) Carmelites after having visions of St. Joseph.

Chinese slaves in Portugal most frequently held this job which they conducted with the knowledge of Hu Sihui's Yinshan Zhengyao. Members of this profession in Europe often read Guillaume (ghee-YAHM) Tirel's updated version of Vinidarius's translation of the ancient Roman Apicius (ah-pik-EE-us).

The slave translator Tristán de la China accompanied the Loaísa (loh-AI-zuh) expedition, on which Francisco de Hoces (HO-thays) recorded the first report of this geographical location. Willem Scouten named this location, which Ferdinand Magellan avoided by traversing the "dragon's tail."

answers: weights of a neural network [prompt on w]
classification [or binary classification; accept word forms such as classifier]
parts: Name these quantities, which are the only learnable parameters besides the biases. A common technique uses the chain rule to find the derivative of the error with respect to one of these quantities, which is then updated via gradient descent.

This function works well as an activation function when running backpropagation, since it satisfies the equation f prime equals f times "one minus f." This sigmoid-shaped function is often used to model population growth.
Neural networks are often used for this supervised learning task. Support vector machines compute a maximum-margin hyperplane to perform the binary form of this task.

answers: Rafael (Leónidas) Trujillo (Molina) [accept El Jefe or The Chief]
The Brief Wondrous Life of Oscar Wao
parts: Name this character, described as a "Failed Cattle Thief" by Yunior. A golden mongoose leads Beli out of a cane field after she is beaten by this character's goons.
The mongoose saves Beli in this Junot Díaz novel about a nerdy Dominican-American teenager whose family is afflicted by a fukú curse.

Yunior quotes the last line "Nothing ever ends, Adrian" from this book while imagining himself talking with Oscar one last time. Walter Kovacs carries a sign reading "The End Is Nigh" at the beginning of this book.

Name this Greek festival, whose secret rituals only women were allowed to take part in. It was usually associated with the sowing of seeds, and consisted of three days called the Anodos (an-oh-dohs), Nesteia (nest-ee-ah) and Kalligeneia (kal-li-gen-ee-ah).
The Thesmophoria (thes-moh-for-ee-ah) honoured both Persephone and this mother of hers, who was the Greek goddess of agriculture.

The Thesmophoria began with the women ritually sacrificing these animals, which were then left to decompose for months in pits called megara (meh-gah-rah). Artemis sent one of these animals following King Oeneus' (oi-neh-oos) failure to make sacrifices to her.
Name this father of pragmatism who wrote "How to Make Our Ideas Clear" and "The Fixation of Belief."

Another one of Peirce's essays, "On a New List of Categories," divides these objects into categories of "firstness," "secondness," and "thirdness." These objects are studied in the field of semiotics.

Peirce's theory of semiotics divides signs into icons, symbols, and these objects, which evidence a connection between the signifier and signified. They share their name with a type of expression whose content depends on context, such as "today" or "I."
The speaker's cone oscillates when a magnetic field produced by the voice coil continuously changes direction in this paradigm, which is contrasted with direct current.

The "damping factor" of a speaker measures the ratio of this quantity for load and source values of the amplifier. This quantity equals reactance for an ideal capacitor, as they should have 0 resistance.

Thiele and Small's parameters for a speaker split this quantity into electrical and mechanical components. The width of a band-pass filter is inversely proportional to this quantity, which is the frequency at the center over the difference of the frequency cutoffs for filters.

answers: Father Coughlin ("KOG-lin" or "KOFF-lin") [or Charles Edward Coughlin; prompt on, but DO NOT REVEAL, the radio priest]
parts: Name this priest known for his anti-Semitic, pro-fascist screeds. He was the founding pastor of the Shrine of the Little Flower in Royal Oak, near metro Detroit.
Coughlin was nicknamed for his use of this medium, whose early religious pioneers included Bob Jones Sr. and S. Parkes Cadman. The Fireside Chats were delivered via this medium.
The first radio sermon is often credited to this Pentecostalist, who published Bridal Call and was found in a hospital in Douglas, Arizona after an incident.

answers: Brian Eno [or Brian Peter George St John le Baptiste de la Salle Eno]
parts: Name this English musician who was inspired by a flight to Cologne for his 1979 album Music for Airports. This musician's production credits include the Talking Heads album Remain in Light and David Bowie's Berlin Trilogy.
Eno's Music for Airports helped pioneer this genre of slow, repetitive music with an "atmospheric" and calm quality. Composers like Ludovico Einaudi have popularized this genre.

This other ambient composer included clips of Tilda Swinton reading Kafka on his album The Blue Notebooks. Neuroscientist David Eagleman helped this composer create the eight-and-a-half-hour album Sleep.

answers: the dead [or Myortvovo; accept Drive Your Plow Over the Bones of the Dead or The House of the Dead]
parts: Name this type of person. A Fyodor Dostoyevsky novel about his time in a prison camp is titled for The House of these people.

This other Eastern European author wrote about a book containing biographies of everyone who died since 1789 in the story "The Encyclopedia of the Dead." Plagiarism concerns have dogged this author's collection A Tomb for Boris Davidovich.
The title of The Encyclopedia of the Dead possibly alludes to Kiš's massive influence from this Irish modernist, whose story "The Dead" appears in the collection Dubliners.

Name this 1957 work that divides the title field of study into "tacts" and "mands" among other things. It was the subject of a scathing critique by Noam Chomsky in Language, which argued its writer overly relied on teaching to explain language acquisition.

This psychologist compared Chomsky's review to "St. George slaying the dragon." Inspired by Lev Vygotsky, this social interactionist coined the term "scaffolding" to describe how children learn language.
Many empiricist theories of language development draw on this psychologist’s theory of cognitive development in which language emerges during the sensorimotor stage.

answers: marriage [accept word forms like getting married; accept equivalents]
mahr [accept mehr, meher, mehrieh, or mahriyeh]
parts: Name this action, which in Islam, is not possible to perform during a three-month period known as iddah (ih-dah). In July of 2019, India criminalized an instant form of undoing this action that involved repeating talaq three times over any medium.
Tahleel marriage is illegal according to one of these texts recorded by Ibn Majah (ib-neh mah-jah). These texts record the sayings of Muhammad.

Upon initiating a divorce through talaq, the husband must pay his wife this Islamic "dowry" that is stipulated at the time of marriage. Following marriage, the wife receives an initial portion of this payment known as muqaddam (mook-ah-dahm).

answers: diary [accept Diary of a Young Naturalist or A Journal of the Plague Year]
fishing [or angling or The Compleat Angler, accept word forms]
parts: In 2020, the teenage author Dara McAnulty won the prize for a book titled for one of these works of a Young Naturalist. One of these works is the best-known work of Samuel Pepys.

Richard Askwith was shortlisted for the prize in 2015 for his memoir about this activity. This activity is the subject of a Japanese memoir that imitates Raymond Carver in its title, What I Talk About When I Talk About this activity.

A 2020 nominee by Lamorna Ash is subtitled for a "town" whose commerce is focused on this activity. A 1653 nonfiction work published by its author's friend Richard Marriot is titled for a practitioner of this activity.

answers: t-tubules [or transverse tubules; prompt on partial answers]
parts: Name this ion which can coordinate to the EF-hand motif.

The L-type channels in these structures are the primary path to move calcium from the cell membrane to the sarcoplasmic reticulum. These structures meet the sarcoplasmic reticulum's cisternae (sis-TUR-nee) at diads and triads.
T-tubules allow for the quick propagation of these events into muscle cells. These events involve rapid polarization and depolarization of the membrane and allow for neuron-to-neuron signalling.

Name this dictator of South Korea, who issued the Yushin Constitution to consolidate his power. This dictator's investment in chaebols such as Lucky-Goldstar is credited with bringing about the "Miracle on the Han River."

Following Park's assassination, Chun Doo-hwan declared martial law, leading to this series of student uprisings at Chonnam University. Jurgen Hinzpeter was the only one to capture these protests on film.

Park granted a chaebol in this industry land in the city of Ulsan to build this industry's largest assembly plant in the world. Mitsubishi, a Japanese company in this industry, manufactured the Zero fighter plane during World War II.

answers: Palace of Versailles [or Château de Versailles]
Le Brun [accept Charles Le Brun or Élisabeth Vigée Le Brun]
Babylon [or Bābilim or Bābiru] (The last clue is from John Martin's depiction of Belshazzar's Feast)
parts: Name this baroque French palace where Crossing the Rhine and The King Governs Alone adorn the ceiling of the Hall of Mirrors.

An artist with this surname was the "First Painter" to Louis XIV, and founded the French Academy after painting the walls of Versailles. A painter who hyphenated her maiden name Vigée (vee-jay) with this surname was the portraitist of Marie Antoinette.

Charles Le Brun depicted Alexander riding a chariot pulled by an elephant while entering this city. A man in black preaches to a crowd in white in a massive temple in a John Martin painting depicting a feast in this city.

answers: W. G. Sebald [or Winfried Georg Sebald or Max Sebald]
the Holocaust [or Shoah; prompt on World War II]
parts: Name this writer of the long poem After Nature. That poem's English translator, Michael Hamburger, appears in a 1995 novel by this author that includes reflections on Thomas Browne's skull and many black-and-white pictures in the narrative.
Sebald's poem "Somewhere behind Turkenfeld," like much of his prose, obliquely describes the aftermath of this historical event by alluding to the Dachau death camp.
Sebald's poetry is often compared to that of this earlier poet, who Michael Hamburger also translated. The line "Black milk of daybreak" is repeated in this poet's Holocaust poem "Death Fugue."
